text: why are you challenging Jeremy Corbyn
for the lead of the Labour leadership
well I think it's clear that he's lost
the confidence of MPs in the
parliamentary party Tom Watson our
deputy leader who has his own mandate
rosy Winterton the Chief Whip Jon Cryer
who's the chair of the parliamentary
Labour Party and a friend of Jeremy's
have been going to try to say to him
that he needs the confidence of the
parliamentary party to continue he's not
listening you can't lead behind an
office door but maybe he's not listening
because he has a huge mandate from the
party membership as Labour leader he's
won every by-election he's won the
London mayoral election three other
mayoral elections the largest party in
the local government elections why will
you want to carry on but we lost seats
in the local government elections when
we have a Conservative government we
should be doing much better polling
shows that were 7% behind the
Conservatives even after all the tumult
they've been through and more
importantly we lost the EU referendum it
was entirely or even maybe largely his
fault not saying it was entirely
Jeremy's fault but he wasn't connecting
with labour voters and he didn't put the
argument across so I think we need a
strengthened labour party in an
opposition that can unite so we can heal
the country and unfortunately I just
don't think Jeremy can do that job other
than trident what are the major policy
differences well I think I'm on the left
any party that I lead will be an
anti-austerity party because what's
happened in our heartland is that they
have been hit by six years of
conservative cuts piled on to them how
much I understand that's mr. Gordon's
position - I ask you what are the major
policy differences well I think that I
want to lead a strong united opposition
to get into government now Jeremy was
asked three times in that interview this
morning whether he thought he could win
a general election he didn't say yes I
know I understand where our for our
support I understand that you think you
lose
we came into politics to represent we
need a Labour Party that can position
itself as a strong united opposition and
win a general but that's in your view
having a leader that's a winner I'll ask
again what are the major policy
differences I don't think that Jeremy
has managed to get across a strategy for
winning I'm on the left my politics came
out of what happened when I was growing
up when my parents my mama seems just my
dad a printer were prevented from
fulfilling their opportunities because
we had Labour government I was able to
fulfill mine I want a Labour Party that
can deliver that Jeremy doesn't talk
about I was just trying to find out what
the differences over let me move on
he's the incumbent leader should he not
surely be on the ballot against you as a
right well the Labour Party rules and
precedent is that if there's a challenge
there has to be 51 nominations for the
incumbent Jeremy should know this
because Tony been challenged the venn
incumbent neil kinnock in 1988 Jeremy
was the campaign manager and Neil had to
get fifty-one nominations but really
that's a matter for the national
executive not clear that he had to do it
and even mr. Kinnick can't remember if
he had to do it or whether he did it to
show the strength but put aside the
rules don't you think most people
watching this program not just Corbin
Easter's not even just labour members
would find it strange that the man who
won the leadership fairly and decisively
no challenge by you is not automatically
allowed to defend his title but that is
not clear from the Labour Party rules
and the National Executive Committee
will make a decision on that but let me
just say anyone who aspires to lead the
parliamentary party who can't get 51
members 20% of the parliamentary party
to back them is not going to be able to
do the job properly and we are in
challenging times the brexit vote we've
had a government that's gone missing in
action we need a strong lead from the
Labour Party if we're going to protect
our communities
were going to be the hardest-hit nothing
of that lead is coming from Jeremy at
the moment but you are also the
self-styled party of fairness and don't
you think that it will offend against
natural justice against most people's
idea of fairness if the incumbent who is
challenged by you is not allowed to
fight you in an election won't that just
seem incredible forget the rules forget
the NEC just offends against fairness
look I don't know what the outcome of
the NE sees me I am ready to fight a
leadership challenge and have debates
about the future of our party with
anyone be it Jeremy or anyone else who
seeks to stand then McCluskey of unite
perhaps the most important person in the
labour party why wouldn't you say that
well he says that keeping mr. Corbyn off
the ballot would cause quote lasting
division in the party and he's right it
would win it this isn't about the Labour
Party being split or divided it's about
it being an effective and united
opposition to make our democracy work so
that we can challenge this Conservative
government which has done such damage
with the brexit vote and I want to say
that if you think that we should have a
strong and effective Labour Party a
strong democracy and challenge the
Conservatives join the Labour Party now
do it today you can do it online almost
130,000 new members have joined labour
since the referendum do you have any
idea who they are
well I'm sure Labour Party nationally
knows who they are not vetted I want I
want more people who have been elected I
have no idea what the Labour Party
office are doing about the new members
but I think it's important that people
who think that we need a strong
opposition join this battle now join the
Labour Party make us stronger
participate in the debate we took on
which means the hundred thirty thousand
who have already joins us the referendum
they should be allowed to vote well
again that's
matter for the National Executive
Committee people they look like people
joining now that you're calling him to
do it they're not gonna be they were
allowed to vote in the past we haven't
even opened up the three-pound
membership which was such a feature of
the last campaign and let's bear this in
mind
Andrew 150,000 people are going to be
picking the next conservative prime
minister we've had nearly that number
join in the last week mr. Coughlin would
say he won by what was it over two
hundred thirty five thousand forty for
him but do you expect to be the only
challenger to mr. Corbyn I have no idea
have you spoken to Owen Smith we have
spoken but not recently
I have no idea I'm concentrating on
launching my campaign which I'll be
doing tomorrow but from your point of
view it would surely would be absurd for
you and Owen Smith or someone else from
the middle of the party of the moderate
left to split the anti Corbin vote that
would be suicide well what we have to do
is get on with doing our own planning
and see what happens in the future I'm
concentrated on getting my campaign up
and running on launching it tomorrow and
joining a battle to have a strong and
United Labor Party than you can give
hope back to our country you voted for
the Iraq war yep do you regret that not
I do regret it
and certainly if I'd have known then
what I know now I wouldn't have
supported it I think the important thing
from the Chilcott report is that we
learn the lessons of that so those
mistakes can never be made again in the
future would you go as far as John
Prescott this morning who also voted for
it to say that he now regards the war is
illegal well Chilcott hasn't said that
no I think it's important I think it's
important that we learn the lesson do
you think it was illegal the evidence at
the time and the Attorney General's
advice at the time wasn't to that effect
and it's no good trying to second-guess
what happened subsequently we need to
learn the lessons and we need to ensure
that if anything like that happens in
the future we have more robust ways of
test
these assertions but you know I also
think that we've got a country divided
at the moment no did you say uncertain
about the future you have said that to
make certain that we address those
problems as well I understand that but
forgive me too because we haven't got
too much time for just moving on there's
going to be a motion before Parliament
likely next week holding a Tony Blair
for contempt of Parliament because of
Iraq how will you vote well I haven't
seen the motion yet we have to make
certain that we don't spend our time in
Parliament just exacting revenge I think
Tony Blair has been put rightly through
the mill about the decisions he took the
Chilcott report did that and I think we
should be something we would be far
better learning the lessons and making
certain that we don't fall into the same
mistakes if god forbid there should be a
future occasion where these decisions
are made a final question because you
talk about uniting labour in order to be
able to unite the country and take on
the Tories but if you lose in mr corbyn
wins or even if you win and mr corbyn
lose isn't the clear indications that
your party could be heading very serious
schism either way now I think we need to
heal the party under effective
leadership so we can have a chance of
winning that general election which may
come much sooner than we all think and
that is my main aim with launching this
leadership bid at this time if he wins
will you accept the result well you have
to accept the result of any would you
then go back into the shadow calculate
the result back into the Shadow Cabinet
you have to accept the result of any
democratic process but I am focused on
winning this and I'm not going to
speculate about what happens afterwards
all right Andrew the busy summer ahead
thank you thank you
